facts.text: Temple of Sri Kodandaramaswami in village Varagali, Nellore district, built in middle of last century by Burla Rangareddi who managed it and its properties during his lifetime.
After Burla Rangareddi's death, his son Venkata Subbareddi managed the temple.
By deed dated August 19, 1898, Venkata Subbareddi relinquished his interest in the properties in favour of Vemareddi Rangareddi, whose family members are defendants 1 to 5.
Plaintiff filed petition before Assistant Commissioner for Hindu Religious Endowments, Nellore, alleging mismanagement by first defendant.
Notice issued to 1st defendant, who contested claiming properties were family properties, not temple properties.
Assistant Commissioner enquired and recommended to Hindu Religious Endowments Board, Madras, that a scheme of management be framed.
Board commenced proceedings for scheme, issued notice to 1st defendant, who reiterated temple was private.
Board by order dated October 5, 1949 held temple was public.

On January 18, 1950, 1st defendant filed O.P. No. 3 of 1950 in District Judge, Nellore: (1) set aside Board's order, (2) declare temple private under s.6 cl.17 Madras Act II of 1927, (3) declare scheduled properties personal family properties.
Commissioner HRE Board Madras impleaded as sole respondent; plaintiff later impleaded as 2nd respondent.
Respondents contested: temple public, properties temple properties.
Petition not disposed for years due to repeal of Madras Act II of 1927, enactment of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951, formation of Andhra Pradesh.
Commissioner HRE Andhra Pradesh impleaded as 1st respondent.

Compromise between petitioners 1-5 and Commissioner (1st respondent); District Judge recorded compromise and passed decree dated October 28, 1954 (Ex. B-11): temple public u/s.6 cl.17 1951 Act; petitioners 1-4 hereditary trustees; Sch A properties personal subject to annual charge of 12-1/2 putties paddy and Rs.600; Commissioner can associate up to 2 non-hereditary trustees; 2nd respondent's rights unaffected.

Plaintiff instituted suit on October 31, 1955 for declaration that provision in compromise decree declaring Sch lands personal properties of defendants 1-5 and not temple properties was not valid and binding on temple.
Defendants objected: plaintiff cannot attack part of decree, must attack entirety.
Trial court dismissed suit: defective, barred by s.93 1951 Act.
Plaintiff appealed AS No. 312 of 1957 to Andhra Pradesh High Court; filed MP 6422/1962 for amendment to declare entire compromise decree invalid and not binding on temple.
High Court allowed amendment, held it cured defect; s.93 not bar, s.42 Specific Relief Act not exhaustive; suit maintainable; allowed appeal, remanded to trial court dated August 7, 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit is barred by s.42 of the Specific Relief Act as plaintiff is mere worshiper without legal character or right to property.
Whether the compromise decree in O.P. No.3/1950 is invalid because Commissioner did not represent the deity.
Whether the compromise decree exceeded the scope of proceedings under s.84(2) of Madras Act II of 1927.

petitioner_arguments.text: Declaratory suits governed exclusively by s.42 Specific Relief Act; plaintiff as mere worshiper has no legal character or right to temple properties; suit seeks to set aside part of compromise decree without declaring legal character; conditions of s.42 not satisfied, suit not maintainable.

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise decree beyond scope of O.P. No.3/1950 under s.84(2) Madras Act II of 1927 as amended petition sought declaration on properties outside purview.

court_reasoning.text: Suit not governed by s.42 Specific Relief Act; it seeks declaration that compromise decree deprived deity of title to trust properties, which is substantial relief with coercive effect; falls under general CPC provisions like s.9; worshiper entitled to declaration invalidating improper alienation by shebait.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.42 not exhaustive; declaration re deity's rights maintainable by worshiper.

court_reasoning.text: Commissioner under s.20 1951 Act has superintendence/control but no authority to represent deity in judicial proceedings; only shebait represents deity; where shebait negligent or guilty, worshiper can sue as next friend; no representation of deity in O.P., so compromise not binding on deity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deity not represented in O.P. No.3/1950.

court_reasoning.text: O.P. under s.84(2) Madras Act II of 1927 to set aside Board's order declaring public temple and declare private; prayer re properties personal outside purview even after amendment post-1951 Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compromise decree exceeded scope of proceedings.

holdings.text: Suit maintainable outside purview of s.42 Specific Relief Act; worshiper can seek declaration that alienation invalid and not binding on deity.
Compromise decree in O.P. No.3/1950 invalid and not binding on temple as deity not represented and exceeded scope of s.84(2).
Compromise decree exceeded scope of O.P. proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Fischer v. Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit to declare act in contravention of statute void not within s.42 Specific Relief Act.
S.42 not apply to suit setting aside compromise decree obtained by fraud; declaration granted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheoparsan Singh v. Ramnandan Prasad Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Plaintiffs not entitled under s.42 as no legal character where will affirmed by court.
Worshippers are cestui que trustent entitled to protect temple interests.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kalyana Venkataramana Ayyangar v. Kasturiranga Ayyangar
precedents_cited.relevance: Worshiper can get declaration alienation not binding on deity, but not possession.
Worshiper entitled to declaratory decree against improper alienation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdur Rahim v. Mahomed Barkat Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit for declaration property wakf maintainable by interested persons; not bound by compromise.
Deity should be represented by disinterested next friend appointed by court.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of temple; proceedings to set aside Board order declaring public temple.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of temple; Commissioner's superintendence/control but no representation authority; not bar to suit.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Declaratory relief; not exhaustive or bar to suit protecting deity's title.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: General jurisdiction for declaratory suits outside Specific Relief Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by defendants, set aside trial court decree, and granted declaratory decree to plaintiff-respondent No.1 that compromise decree in O.P. No.3/1950 is not valid and binding on Sri Kodandaramaswami temple.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaratory decree that compromise decree Ex. B-11 not valid and binding on temple.

key_quotes.text: "the present suit is not governed by s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds suit maintainable independently of s.42.

key_quotes.text: "as there was no representation of the deity in that judicial proceeding it is manifest that the compromise decree cannot be binding upon the deity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason for invalidity of compromise.

key_quotes.text: "Such a declaration was outside the purview of s. 84(2) of Madras Act II of 1927 and could not have been granted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
